questions.text: Superficial part of deltoid ligament contains all fibers EXCEPT
questions.solution:
The anterior tibiotalar ligament is part of the deep fibres of the deltoid ligament and not the superficial fibers.

The Medial collateral ligament (deltoid ligament) is a strong, triangular band, attached to the apex and the anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus.

Of its Superficial fibres:

  • Tibionavicular fibres: It blends with the medial margin of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament to form the spring ligament.
  • Tibiocalcaneal fibres: It descends almost vertically to the entire length of the sustentaculum tali of Calcaneum.
  • Posterior tibiotalar: It passes posterolaterally to the medial side of the talus and its medial tubercle.

The Deep fibres:

  • Anterior tibiotalar: It passes from the tip of the medial malleolus to the non-articular part of the medial talar surface.

questions.text: Maximum source of linoleic acid
questions.solution:
• Sunflower oil and safflower oil are the rich sources of linoleic acid, an omega (ω)-6 fatty acid.
  • Essential fatty acids are those that cannot be synthesized in the body, it should be supplied from the diet.

ω-3 fatty acids:

  • Alpha linolenic acid.
  • Eicosa-penta-enoic acid.
  • Docosa hexanoic acid.

ω -6 fatty acids:

  • Linoleic acid.
  • Arachidonic acid.
    • Arachidonic acid is the precursor for synthesis of prostaglandins, leukotrienes and thromboxanes.
    • In general ω -3 fatty acids are beneficial and low ω 6: ω 3 ratio shows prevention against cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Sulphur containing amino acid is
questions.solution:
Cysteine is :

Sulphur containing nutritionally non-essential glucogenic amino acid.

It is synthesized in the body from methionine as follows:

  • Methionine following it conversion to homocysteine, combines with serine to form cystathione catalyzed by cystathionine beta synthase.
  • Cystathionase cleaves cystathione to cysteine and homoserine.
  • The two molecules of cysteine combine to form Cystine.
  • There are many disorders associated with cystine metabolism which are as follows,
    • Homocystinurias – Cystathionine beta synthase.
    • Cystine – lysinuria (cystinuria) – defect in renal absorption of cystine, lysine, arginine, ornithine.
    • Cystinosis – defective carrier mediated transport of cystine leading to accumulation of cystine in the cells.

The studies shows elevated homocysteine levels is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease, but the cause is unknown.

questions.text: Protein is purified using ammonium sulfate by
questions.solution:
Purification of proteins is an essential process employed to isolate proteins of interest from a complex mixture.

It can be accomplished by many ways as follows.

  • Salting out – Protein can be precipitated out by concentrated salt solutions like ammonium sulphate, this is called as salting out process.
  • Chromatography: Process of separating the protein based on its differential distribution between a mobile phase and stationary phase.

 It can be done by many methods:

  1. Size exclusion – based on the size of the molecule, also known as molecular sieving.
  2. Ion exchange – based on the charge of the molecule.
  3. Thin layer/ paper chromatography.
  4. Affinity chromatography.
  • Mass spectrometry – proteins can be separated based on the mass to charge ratio, considered as the specific method.
  • Protein purification plays an important role in proteomics.

questions.text: Breath sounds are decreased in following except
questions.solution:
Breath sounds decrease in conditions like:

  • Pleural effusion.
  • Empyema.
  • Pneumothorax.
  • Thickened pleura.
  • Edematous chest wall.
  • Malignant infiltration of chest wall.
  • Respiratory muscle paralysis.
  • Atelectasis.

questions.text: FNAC doesn’t help in the diagnosis of
questions.solution: To diagnose follicular carcinoma, one must demonstrate capsular / vascular invasion which can’t be commented on FNAC.

questions.text: The fundoscopic picture shown below is seen in
questions.solution:
The slide shows cherry red spot which is a feature of CRAO.

Central retinal artery occlusion:

Risk factors are:

  • Heart disease.
  • Carotid artery disease.
  • Mucormycosis.
  • Varicella infection.
  • Radiation exposure.
  • Trauma.

Clinical features are:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision.
  • Severe edema- whole retina looks white in colour.
  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries.
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance.
  • Cherry red spots.

Cherry red spots are also seen in :

  • Berlin’s edema.
  • CRAO.
  • Tay Sach’s.
  • Neimann Pick.
  • Gauchers.

Treatment:

  • Dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V Acetazolamide or ocular massage.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with acne conglobata. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Acne conglobata is a severe form of nodulocystic acne and isotretinoin is the treatment of choice. 

Acne conglobata typically presents with tender, disfiguring, interconnecting comedones, cysts, inflammatory nodules, and deep burrowing abscesses which may be located on the face, torso, or limbs.

Acne Treatment :

  • Elimination of comedones by normalization of follicular keratinization,
  • Decreasing sebaceous gland activity,
  • Decreasing the population of P. acnes, and decreasing inflammation.

Minimal to moderate

  • Adequately to local therapy alone.
  • Topical agents such as retinoic acid, benzoyl peroxide, or salicylic acid.
  • Topical antibacterial agents such as azelaic acid, topical erythromycin, or clindamycin.

Moderate to severe acne

  • Systemic therapy, such as doxycycline, 100 mg bid.
  • Minocycline is also useful.

Severe nodulocystic acne

  • Synthetic retinoid isotretinoin. 
  • Severe adverse events such as teratogenicity.
  • In addition, patients receiving this medication develop extremely dry skin and cheilitis and must be followed for the development of hypertriglyceridemia.
  • Recently, there have also been concerns that isotretinoin is associated with severe depression in some patients.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: Most common site of hypertensive bleed in brain is
questions.solution:
Basal ganglia and putamen in particular is the most common cause of hypertensive bleed. Hypertension is the most common cause of intracerebral haemorrhages. According to the typical locations of ICH in order of decreasing frequency:

  • Basal ganglia haemorrhage (especially the putamen).
  • Thalamic haemorrhage.
  • Pontine haemorrhage.
  • Cerebellar haemorrhage.

Non contrast CT is the investigation of choice in stroke.

questions.text: In a village the prevalence of a disease is half of the population. Among the diseased population, half are tested positive for a screening test. Among the normal population , half are tested negative for the screening test. All of the following are true about the screening test except

choices.text: Positive predictive value is the same as Negative predictive value
Sensitivity of the test is higher than specificity

questions.solution:
Explanation :

Lets assume population to be 100.

Prevalence is 50%.

Cases = 50.

Normal = 50.

Sensitivity  =  a / a + b  =  50%.

Specificity  = d / d + c =  50%.

Positive Predictive Value = a / a + c = 50%.

Negative Predictive Value = d / d +  b = 50%.

Positive Likelihood ratio   = Sensitivity  /  1- Specificity

                                  = 0.5  / (1  -  0.5)

                          = 1 : 1

  Disease     Total
Screening test   Positive Negetive  
  Positive 25(a) 25(c) 50
  Negetive 25(b) 25(d) 50
Total   50 50

questions.text: The histological picture of schwannoma shows
questions.solution:
Schwannoma (neurilemoma) is one of the few truly encapsulated neoplasms of the human body and is almost always solitary (unless seen as a component of Recklinghausen disease type 2).

HPE :

  • Two different patterns usually can be recognized, designated by Antoni as A and B.
  • The type A areas, which in small tumors comprise almost their entirety, are quite cellular, composed of spindle cells often arranged in a palisading fashion or in an organoid arrangement (Verocay bodies).
  • In type B areas the tumor cells are separated by abundant edematous fluid that may form cystic spaces.
  • Occasionally, isolated cells with bizarre hyperchromatic nuclei are observed particularly common in so-called ancient schwannomas and are of no particular significance.

questions.text: Electrical alternans in ECG is characteristic of
questions.solution:
• Total electrical alternans (P-QRS-T) with sinus tachycardia is a relatively specific sign of pericardial effusion,  usually with cardiac tamponade. 

  

  • The mechanism relates to a periodic swinging motion of the heart in the effusion at a frequency exactly one-half the heart rate.   

                

 

 Electrical alternans   

  • Periodic beat to beat change in electrical/hemodynamic behaviour 

  

  • Total electrical alterans: specific, but not sensitive of effusion 

  

  • ST-T alterans: LV failure, it is considered as noninvasive marker of ventricular arrhythmia 
  • T-U alterans: Torsades de pointes/ acquired long QT syndrome.

questions.text: In Kawasaki disease, the following manifestation appears at:
questions.solution:
The above image shows desquamation of skin from fingers and toes. Desquamation of skin from fingers and toes occurs in the subacute phase (2 – 4 weeks) of Kawasaki disease.

Clinical phase of Kawasaki disease Duration Clinical feature
Acute febrile phase 1-2 weeks Fever, erythema
Subacute 2-4 weeks Desquamation and peeling of fingers and toes onset of coronary artery aneurysm
High risk of sudden death
Convalescence 6-8 weeks Recovery

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented with a 2 cm thyroid nodule. A thyroidectomy was done. The histology picture is given below. What could be the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Microscopic Features of Papillary carcinoma of  thyroid.

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass).
  • Orphan-Annie nuclei.
  • Micronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis in 66% - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old roofer presents to his primary care physician complaining of dyspnea and chronic dry cough. Frontal chest radiograph shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Asbestos is a generic term for several different mineral silicates, including

  • Chrysolite.
  • Amosite.
  • Anthophyllite.
  • Crocidolite.

Asbestosis leads to:

  • Fibrosis.
  • Pleural disease.
  • Lung cancer.
  • Mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that is directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. The disease resembles other forms of diffuse interstitial fibrosis.

Pathogenesis:

Involves oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis.

Chest radiograph

  • Either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields, the diaphragm, and the cardiac border.
  • An indistinct heart border or a "ground-glass" appearance in the lung fields is seen in some cases.
  • Lung cancer is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure.
  • The excess frequency of lung cancer (all histologic types) in asbestos workers is associated with a minimum latency of 15–19 years.
  • Mesotheliomas both pleural and peritoneal, are also associated with asbestos exposure

questions.text: Shortest acting muscle relaxant is
questions.solution:
Mivacurium is the shortest acting competitive blocker.

  • It does not need reversal. It can be used as an alternative to Succinylcholine for endotracheal intubation.
  • It is metabolized rapidly by plasma cholinesterase. Prolonged paralysis can occur in pseudocholinesterase deficiency.
  • Mivacurium is the only non-depolarizing (competitive) blocker that is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase).

questions.text: An elderly woman comes to the hospital with tense bulla with itchiness. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bullous pemphigoid:

  • It is a chronic, inflammatory, subepidermal, blistering disease.
  • If untreated, it can persist for months or years, with periods of spontaneous remissions and exacerbations.
  • The disease can be fatal, particularly in patients who are debilitated.

Bullous pemphigoid may present with several distinct clinical presentations, as follows:

Generalized bullous form:

The most common presentation; tense bullae arise on any part of the skin surface, with a predilection for the flexural areas of the skin.

Vesicular form:

Less common than the generalized bullous type.        

Manifests as groups of small, tense blisters, often on an urticarial/erythematous base.

  • Vegetative form
  • Generalized erythroderma form
  • Urticarial form
  • Nodular form
  • Acral form
  • Infant form

questions.text: Triangle of auscultation is formed by all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Serratus anterior does not form the triangle of auscultation.

 

Triangle of auscultation

Boundaries:

  • Above: Trapezius medially,
  • Below: Latissimus dorsi
  • Laterally: medial border of scapula (inferomedial border of rhomboid muscle)

When arms are folded and person bends forward, the following structures become subcutaneous in the Triangle of Ausculatation.

  • 6th rib
  • 7th rib
  • 6th intercostal space between them overlying the apex of lower pulmonary lobe

Apex of lower lobes of both lungs lie deep to this triangle  On the left side, cardiac orifice of stomach lies deep and sounds  of swallowed liquids can be heard in esophageal obstruction.

questions.text: Direct bronchoscopy can visualize all except
questions.solution:
Direct bronchoscopy is of two types –

Flexible - visualizes:

  • Nose
  • Supraglottis
  • Glottis
  • Trachea
  • Segmental and subsegmental bronchi in both the lungs

Rigid - rigid bronchoscope visualises:

  • Glottis ( vocal cords )
  • Trachea
  • Segmental bronchi

questions.text: Attitude of the leg in femoral shaft fracture
questions.solution: In femoral shaft fracture, the Limb is in Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation.(FABER)

questions.text: Patella dislocation is prevented by
questions.solution:
Patella dislocation is more commonly on the lateral side, and it is stabilized by vastus medialis.

Vastus lateralis pulls laterally to the frontal plane of the femur at an angle of 7 to 10 degrees.

Vastus medialis is divided into two parts:

  • Vastus medialis longus (with its muscle fibers pulling at 15 to 18 degrees medially).
  • Vastus medialis obliquus (with its muscle fibers pulling at a relatively horizontal 50 to 55 degrees medially).

The primary function of Vastus Medialis Obliquus muscle is to stabilize the patella against the lateral pull of Vastus Lateralis, making Vastus Medialis Obliqus the dynamic stabilizer of the Patella.

questions.text: Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome is a familial syndrome due to mutation of gene
questions.solution:
• PTCH1 is a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 9q22 that encodes a cell membrane protein called PATCHED1. PATCHED proteins are negative regulators of the Hedgehog signaling pathway.
  • In the absence of PATCHED proteins, there is unopposed Hedgehog signaling that increases the expression of a number of pro-growth genes.
  • Germline loss-of-function mutations in PTCH1 cause Gorlin syndrome, an inherited autosomal dominant condition also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma  syndrome associated with a high risk of basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma.

questions.text: Cancers are commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Epigenetics concerns reversible, heritable changes in gene expression that occur without mutation.

It has become evident during the past few years that certain tumor suppressor genes may be inactivated, not because of structural changes, but because the gene is silenced by hypermethylation of promoter sequences.

Examples:

  • p14ARF is silenced in colon and stomach cancers, and
  • p16INK4a is silenced in various types of cancers,      
  • BRCA1 in breast cancer,
  • VHL in renal cell cancer,
  • The MLH1 mismatch repair gene in colorectal cancer are frequently silenced by methylation of the promoter.

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient presented to the OPD with this lesion in the left breast. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Paget's disease of the nipple is a superﬁcial manifestation of an underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple and areola, which persists despite local treatment. The nipple is eroded slowly and eventually disappears.
  • Nipple eczema should be biopsied if there is any doubt about its cause. Eczema tends to occur in younger people who have signs of eczema elsewhere (antecubital fossae).
  • Microscopically, Paget’s disease is characterised by the presence of large, ovoid cells with abundant, clear, pale-staining cytoplasm called the Paget's cells in the Malpighian layer of the epidermis.

questions.text: Identify the crystal depicted in urine microscopy
questions.solution:
The above image of urine microscopy shows coffin lid like crystals which are characteristic of struvite crystals.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Image of X ray chest of a 42 year old male is given below. Which of the following statement is incorrect about this condition

choices.text: Most common benign tumour of lung

questions.solution:
• The image shows popcorn calcification which is diagnostic of Pulmonary Hamartoma and it is more common in males.  
  • Pulmonary Hamartoma is the most common benign tumor of the lung and it is manifested by overgrowth of connective tissue mainly cartilage. Pulmonary hamartoma is typically seen in 40-60 year old , more commonly found in males and it is seen as an incidental finding.
  • It is usually present peripherally and has slow growth in the lung.

questions.text: The nucleus involved in Papez circuit is
questions.solution:
The anterior thalamic nucleus projects to the cingulate gyrus in prefrontal lobe and from here the connections to the hippocampus complete a complex closed circuit described as the Papez circuit.

 

PAPEZ CIRCUIT:

  • It is a complex closed circuit that provides a link between the limbic system, hypothalamus and thalamus.  
  • It is concerned with expressive side of emotions and is responsible for resting EEG.

questions.text: Most important extracellular buffer is
questions.solution:
• The bicarbonate buffer system is the most important extracellular buffer.
  • Proteins are among the most plentiful buffers in the body because of their high concentrations, especially within the cells.
  • Buffer : Buffer is a substance that can reversibly bind hydrogen ions.

questions.text: A young frequent traveller presented with pain abdomen, diarrhoea and fever which is gradually increasing in a step latter pattern over past 2 weeks. Blood culture reveals gram negative, motile, non lactose fermenting bacilli. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
History is suggestive of typhoid fever/enteric fever(step ladder type of fever). Causative organism is Salmonella typhi – gram negative bacilli, motile with peritrichous flagella and it is a non lactose fermenter.

 

Cultural characteristics of Salmonella typhi:

  • Selenite F broth and tetrathionate broth are commonly used enrichment media for salmonella.
  • Aerobic and facultative anaerobic.
  • Optimum pH – 6-8.
  • They produce hydrogen sulphide which is responsible for black coloured colonies on deoxycholate and XLD (Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate) agar and jet black colonies with metallic sheen on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium.

- Option b: Brucella is a gram negative, non motile coccobacilli.

- Option c: Shigella is a gram negative, non motile, non sporing and non capsulated bacilli and non lactose fermenter.

- Option d: Q fever is caused by Coxiella burnetti and acute form mainly manifests with respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms doesn't have cyst form in human body
questions.solution:
Trichomonas exists only in trophozoite form which is pear shaped with 5 flagella and an undulating membrane. Cystic stage is not seen.  

Trichomonas is a flagellate and has 3 species:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis – found in vagina and urethra
  • Trichomonas tenax - found in mouth
  • Trichomonas hominis – found in large intestine (caecum)

 

Lifecycle of Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • They divide by binary fission and trophozoites are the infective forms.
  • Sexual transmission is the most important mode of transmission.
  • Other modes of infection are through fomites such as towels and newborns are infected during delivery through infected birth canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding arboviruses

choices.text: Yellow fever is endemic in India
Mosquito of culex vishnoi complex is  the vector of dengue fever
Dengue virus has only one serotype
Kyasanur forest disease is transmitted by ticks

questions.solution:
Kyasanur forest disease is a haemorrhagic fever caused by a flavivirus and transmitted by the bite of ticks, principal vector being Haemaphysalis spinigera.

  • Option a: Yellow fever is not found in India though it forms an important receiving area with large population of Aedes aegypti and non immune humans.
  • Option b: Aedes aegypti is the vector of dengue fever.
  • Option c: Dengue virus has 4 serotypes.

questions.text: Which of the following drug doesn’t need therapeutic drug monitoring?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic drug monitoring is not done for drugs whose effect can be easily measured like antidiabetic drugs (effect can be measured by monitoring blood glucose levels, antihypertensives (effect can be measured by monitoring BP).

Therapeutic blood monitoring refers to a process where the plasma concentration of drug is measured and its dose is adjusted accordingly. It is mainly done for:

  • Drugs which exhibit good correlation between serum level and drug response or toxicity.
  • Drugs having wide variation in pharmacokinetics both intra and inter individual.
  • Drugs having low therapeutic index like digitalis, lithium, antiepileptics, antiarrhythmics, TCAs etc.

It is not done for:

  •  Drugs whose effect can be easily measured like antidiabetics, antihypertensive, anticoagulants.        
  •  Drugs which are activated in the body or produce active metabolites.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 agonist
questions.solution:
Clonidine is a selective alpha 2 agonist.

  • Clonidine is an imidazoline derivative having complex actions.
  • Clonidine is a partial agonist with high affinity and high intrinsic activity at α2 receptors, especially α2A subtype in the brainstem.
  • The major haemodynamic effects result from stimulation of α2A receptors present mainly post-junctionally in the medulla (vasomotor centre).This decreases sympathetic outflow → fall in BP and bradycardia.  
  • Enhanced vagal tone contributes to bradycardia.
  • Plasma NA declines. Though clonidine is capable of reducing NA release from peripheral adrenergic nerve endings (release inhibitory prejunctional α2 action), this does not manifest at clinically used doses.  
  • Clonidine is a moderately potent antihypertensive.

questions.text: The half life of Amiodarone is
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is the longest acting anti-arrhythmic drug. Its half life is 3-8 weeks.

  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.
  • It has widest spectrum of action – Sodium channel blockade, β blockade, potassium channel blockade, and calcium channel blockade.
  • It is incompletely and slowly absorbed from the g.i.t.
  • On daily oral ingestion the action develops over several days, even weeks. However, on i.v. injection, action develops rapidly.  
  • It accumulates in muscle and fat from which it is slowly released and then metabolized in liver mainly by CYP3A4. One metabolite is active.
  • The duration of action is exceptionally long; t½ 3–8 weeks.

questions.text: Name the Rho kinase inhibitor
questions.solution:
Fasudil is a Rho kinase inhibitor.

  • The Rho kinases (ROCK) comprise a family of enzymes that inhibit vascular relaxation and diverse functions (contraction, migration, gene expression etc) of several other cell types.
  • Excessive activity of these enzymes has been implicated in coronary spasm, pulmonary hypertension, apoptosis, and other conditions. Drugs targeting the enzyme have therefore been sought for possible clinical applications.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests.

questions.text: Mc Naughten rule is concerned with
questions.solution:
• Mc Naughten rule states that, if at the time of committing an act, person is of unsound mind and he is not able to understand the nature and quality of the act he is doing, he cannot be held criminally responsible for such an act.
  • In India, the law of Criminal responsibility is under Section 84 I.P.C.
  • The other rules which describes the legal responsibility of insane are:
    • Durham rule
    • Curren’s rule
    • The Irresistible Impulse Test
    • Federal rule or American Law Institute test (ALT)

questions.text: Punishment for infanticide comes under
questions.solution:
In India, infanticide is considered as murder and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

  • Option C: IPC 304 – Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
  • Option D: IPC 306 – Punishment for abetment of suicide.
  • Other relevant sections:
    • Section 317 IPC – Abandoning the foetus.
    • Section 318 IPC – Concealment of birth.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Schneider’s first rank symptom
questions.solution:
Voices commenting on actions i.e. Auditory hallucination is one of the Schneider's first rank symptoms.

 
 
Schneider's first rank symptoms of schizophrenia are:
  • Audible thoughts
  • Voice arguing (referring to patient in third person)
  • Voices commenting on one's actions
  • Thought insertion
  • Thought withdrawal
  • Thought broadcasting
  • Made volition
  • Made affect
  • Made feelings
  • Somatic passivity
  • Delusional perception

questions.text: Which of the following is used for recording very low air velocity
questions.solution:
Kata Thermometer is quiet sensitive to slight air movements as low as 10 feet per minute and hence used to record low air velocity.

  • Usually air velocity is measured by an instrument called anemometer.
  • The velocity of the wind is indicated on a counter called the cyclometer, placed in the anemometer box.

questions.text: The mode of inheritance of Duchenne muscular dystrophy is
questions.solution:
• Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common neuromuscular disease affecting all races and ethnic groups.
  • Inherited as X-linked recessive trait.
  • The abnormal gene for DMD is at xp21 locus which is one of the LARGEST GENE.
Disease Mode of inheritence
Duchenne muscular distrophy X linked recessive
Becker muscular distrophy X linked recessive
Myotonia congenita Autosomal dominant
Emery Dreifuss syndrome X linked recessive

questions.text: Cyclopropagative type of life cycle is seen in
questions.solution:
Malaria shows cyclopropogative type of transmission.  

Disease Transmission
Scrub typhus Transovarian transmission- agent transmitted vertically from infected female to her progeny in vector
Filaria Cyclodevelopmental transmission- Microfilaria in mosquito
Malaria Cyclopropagative transmission- Plasmodium in mosquito
Plague Propagative transmission- Plague bacilli in rat flea

 

Methods of biological transmission Explanation
Cyclodevelopmental A part of life cycle is completed in the vector
E.g. W. bancrofti in culex
Cyclopropagative Undergoes development as well as multiplication
E.g.Plasmodium in mosquito
Propagative Simply grows and multiply
Eg. Yersinia pestisin rat flea & all bacterial , viral, rickettsial diseases

questions.text: The Edinburgh Scale is a measure of
questions.solution:
• The Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) is a questionnaire designed to detect postpartum depression. PPD may present in the first week or up to 6 months after delivery.  
  • The Newborn Behavior Assessment Scale (NBAS) is used as a measure of the neurodevelopmental competency of an infant.

questions.text: Paris green mainly kills
questions.solution:
Paris green mainly kills Anopheles larvae only.

  • It is a stomach poison, used as a larvicidal agent.
  • It mainly kills Anopheles larvae as they are surface feeders.
  • When applied in special granule formation, bottom feeding larvae can also be killed.
  • Dose  - 1 kg per hectare of water surface.
  • Applied as 2% dust.

questions.text: The most common route of spread in hepatitis E is
questions.solution:
• MC: feco oral route( contaminated water).
  • As it is restricted to humans, source is human faeces.
  • Vertical transmission is possible.
  • Person to person transmission is uncommon.
  • Incubation period: 2-10 days.
  • HEV virus is detected in faeces 1 week before symptoms.
  • Viremia and faecal shedding persist for 2 and 4 weeks after illness respectively.
  • Lab: leukopenia, relative lymphocytosis, elevated alkaline phosphatase.
  • Self limited illness, fulminant hepatic failure only in pregnant females(upto 22%). Diagnosis is by HEV RNA in stool and IgM anti HEV in serum.

questions.text: Treatment of choice of a 28 weeks pregnant female with pain due to fibroid of fundus of size 10 x 10 cm is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a case of red degeneration of fibroid complicating pregnancy. Red degeneration is conservatively treated.

Management of fibroid during pregnancy.

  • During pregnancy, surgery is contraindicated, except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid if it undergoes torsion. 
  • Acute retention of urine is treated by continuous catheterization for 48–72 h, when the growing uterus rises above the pelvic brim.
  • Red degeneration merits conservative treatment.
    • Bed rest
    • Analgesics

questions.text: During ovulation, which of the following is released from ovary following rupture of mature Graafian follicles
questions.solution:
Ovulation is the process by which a secondary oocyte is released from the Graafian follicle.

  • With each Ovarian cycle, a number of follicles begin to develop, but usually, only one reaches full maturity.
  • When the secondary follicle is mature, a surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) induces the preovulatory growth phase. Meiosis I is completed, resulting in formation of two daughter cells of unequal size, each with 23 double-structured chromosomes. One cell, the secondary oocyte, receives most of the cytoplasm; the other, the first polar body, receives practically none.
  • The cell then enters meiosis II but arrests in metaphase II approximately 3 hours before ovulation. Meiosis II is completed only if the oocyte is fertilized, otherwise the cell degenerates approximately 24 hours after ovulation.

questions.text: Which is not a part of the quadruple test for Down’s syndrome during 2nd trimester screening
questions.solution:
Quadruple test (QUAD) includes:

  • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • Dimeric inhibin-A
  • hCG

Quad screen can detect trisomy 21 in 85% of cases.

Levels of serum analytes in cases with trisomy 21:

  • hCG—increased
  • uE3—reduced
  • inhibin A—elevated
  • MSAFP—reduced

questions.text: Chorioretinitis sclopetaria is seen in which of the following
questions.solution:
Chorioretinitis sclopetaria is an eye injury in which a firearm projectile (bullet) passes nearby the globe without perforating it, causing damage to the retina and choroid. Features :

  • Also called as proliferative plastic chorioretinitis or proliferative lagrange chorioretinitis.
  • May be associated with commotio retinae.
  • Can progress to vitreous haemorrhage or retinal detachment.

questions.text: For a face to pubis delivery to occur from a right occipito-posterior position, the head needs to rotate by
questions.solution:
Face to pubis delivery occurs after a short or 1/8th posterior rotation of head from an occipito-posterior position.

The head moves 1/8th of circle in opposite direction of internal rotation thus turning the face to look towards the mother's left thigh (ROP)

In approximately 20 percent of labors, the fetus enters the pel- vis in an occiput posterior (OP) position. The right occiput posterior (ROP) is slightly more common than the left in LOP.

Other kinds of rotation :

  • Option A : Short anterior 1/8th of circle – results in a deep transverse arrest (DTA).
  • Option B : Long anterior 3/8th of circle – results in normal delivery.
  • Option C : Non rotation –If no rotation toward the symphysis takes place, the occiput may remain in the direct occiput posterior position, a condition known as persistent occiput posterior,
    resulting in an obstructed delivery.

questions.text: Implantation theory of endometriosis was given by
questions.solution:
Implantation theory of endometriosis was first given by Sampson.

Other options :

  • Option A. Mayer and Ivanoff  - Theory of  Coelomic metaplasia.
  • Option C. Halban et.al  - Metastatic theory.
  • Option D. - Carl von rokitansky – first described Endometriosis.
